title: Sets - Collections of Unique Values
description: Learn how to work with sets for efficient membership testing and set operations

content.introduction:
Sets are collections of unique values of the same ordinal type (like integers, characters, or enumeration values). Unlike arrays, sets are unordered and automatically prevent duplicates.

Sets are perfect for checking membership, tracking options, and performing mathematical set operations.

### What You'll Learn
- Declaring and initializing sets
- Adding and removing elements
- Checking membership with the `in` operator
- Set operations (union, intersection, difference)
- Practical uses of sets

concepts.title: Set Declaration
concepts.description: Declare sets using 'set of' followed by an ordinal type. Sets can contain integers, characters, or enumeration values within a specific range

concepts.title: Set Literals
concepts.description: Initialize sets using square brackets with comma-separated values: [1, 2, 3] or ['a', 'b', 'c']

concepts.title: Membership Testing
concepts.description: Use the 'in' operator to check if a value is in a set: if x in mySet then...

concepts.title: Set Operations
concepts.description: Combine sets with + (union), * (intersection), - (difference). These create new sets based on set theory

exercises.title: Prime Checker
exercises.description: Create a set of prime numbers from 1 to 20 and check if given numbers are prime.
hints: Initialize the set using square brackets
Use the 'in' operator to check membership
Test with both prime and non-prime numbers

exercises.title: Days of Operation
exercises.description: A store is open Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday. Check if it's open on different days using sets.
hints: Use the enumeration type TDay for day names
Create a set containing Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday
Use the 'in' operator to check if a day is in openDays
Test with both open and closed days

exercises.title: Permission System
exercises.description: Create a simple permission system using sets. A user can have Read, Write, and Execute permissions.
hints: Define an enumeration for permission types
Create separate sets for user and admin permissions
Use set intersection (*) to find common permissions

content.summary:
Excellent work on sets! You've learned:

- Declaring sets: `set of 1..10` or `set of Char`
- Set literals: `[1, 2, 3]` or `['a', 'b', 'c']`
- Membership testing: `if x in mySet then`
- Union (+): combines elements from both sets
- Intersection (*): elements in both sets
- Difference (-): elements in first set but not second
- Subset testing: `setA <= setB`

Sets are powerful for membership testing, permissions, options, and mathematical set operations!
